Things need to be gift-y, which is hard to define, but basically imagine if you received the thing you're pitching. Would it show you the giver loves you and knows you or is it just stuff? If the latter, please don't pitch it! ##journorequest #giftguide #eid

I am especially interested in companies founded by Muslim people, companies that are inclusive (i.e. if all your models are skinny and white it's unlikely I'll think you're right to include), and companies that have sustainability and ethical practices at heart. #journorequest
This guide will include presents for adults and children, and I'm open to products and experiences from charities, big brands and independents. #journorequest #giftguide #eid

RT @tanyabyrne: @sarahshaffi This is brilliant, Sarah. Thank you. I‚Äôve had to flag many of these myself, but one of the things I encounter‚Ä¶
@JustAGalAndADog Sometimes I am very surprised, other times not so much because the editorial process can still often involve a group of people coming from a very narrow set of perspectives.
@JustAGalAndADog Publishers bring me in at various stages of the process, but I often think (and I've tweeted about this before) that sensitivity readers are brought in to the process too late.
@dylanblue3 @Joannechocolat I'm not often informed, and I don't ask to be!
Also, do give this very good piece by @Joannechocolat a read. It offers a valuable insight into the perspective of an author who has has sensitivity reads done: https://t.co/fNNupJApmZ

That was a short and non-exhaustive list, which I hope shows that sensitivity reads aren't about stifling creativity, but about making better books. Am happy to answer good faith questions, bad faith questions will see the user blocked.
8. One book had a male character who, while it wasn't explicitly said, was coded as gay using extremely old and offensive stereotypes, including that people gave him the nickname "Nancy".
Are they Kenyan? Nigerian? Pakistani? Afghan? Being specific makes for better characters and books, IF a writer does their research, rather than just uses generic stereotypes.

7. I was vague earlier, on purpose, about the exact ethnicity of an Asian character, but I have multiple times come across characters being described as African or Asian. My advice is always to be specific.
6. One contemporary book had an Iranian political refugee at its centre, and was set in our real world, but seemed to conflate Iran and Syria.
5. In one book, EVERY SINGLE female character was described by what they were wearing and how they looked (the men were not), and they were shallow, lazy and passive for the entire novel.
4. A neurodivergent character in a book was described as "mentally subnormal" and "mentally defective" among other things, which I think we can all agree have never been acceptable phrases.
I suggested that the author apply the same thinking to writing the Black characters as they did to the characters of other ethnicities, with the result hopefully being more rounded characters.

3. A book I read had a number of characters of different ethnicities, but the Black characters were ONLY described by their skin colour. All the other characters' ethnicity and nationality was described using multiple cultural and ethnic markers.
In this case, I suggested the character also be given some other interests or personality traits. So rather than asking for anything to be cut, it was about making the character more well-rounded.

2. One book I read had an Asian (I'm going to be vague about where in Asia they were from) character, whose only personality trait was their love of maths. That's it. There's a big problem with Asian people being stereotyped as maths nerds (remember the Oscars?).
Secondly, I find "crazy" is often thrown in when writers means something else ("scary", "absurd", "foolish" and so on) and I think it is just very lazy writing.

1. I often flag use of the word "crazy" with authors. Firstly, I don't think it's a good word to use when talking about people with mental ill health - it carries all sorts of harmful and negative connotations.

In this thread I'll be using examples that may be considered harmful or offensive (and hence why I flagged them with authors). Please look after yourselves and don't read further if you don't feel comfortable.
Finally, I'm issuing a trigger warning for this thread. As sensitivity readers one of our jobs is to look for harmful or offensive language/stereotypes etc.

Also, I charge for sensitivity reads, and I charge for consultations on sensitivity reading as a general concept. If any media takes and uses this thread, expect a hefty invoice (i.e. just don't use my thread).
I'll try and explain with some examples my reasoning for bringing things up and flagging them to the author, and also explain what I suggested could be done. Others I don't think need an explanation.

Other sensitivity readers might not have flagged the things I did, or might have had something contradictory to say. That's because, surprise, we're not all a homogenous mass and we have different lived experiences. Which again is why we give feedback, not demand changes.

Some of these are very specific examples, some are things I've flagged in multiple books. In every case, I have simply noted them in a report, and it is then up to the author (with their editor, like they would for any other type of edit) to choose whether to apply the feedback.
All of things I'm going to talk about are real examples, but I've obviously anonymised them enough that you can't tell what book they're from.

I have done sensitivity reads of fiction and non-fiction, covering everything from picture books to middle grade to adult books, and I've done these over a number of years, for backlist and front list titles.

Given that another article about sensitivity readers is apparently imminent, I'm going to do a thread of things I've picked up in the many sensitivity reads I've done, with the aim of showing what it is we actually do, and how much what we do has been misrepresented.

@Joannechocolat I think the issue is that a lot of people don‚Äôt understand (sometimes wilfully so) what an authenticity read comprises of or might identify.
Maybe, if people are interested, I should give some (heavily anonymised) examples of things that I‚Äôve highlighted through authenticity reads. Would this help?

But if an author wants to carry on publishing books that are lazy in their use of language and that fall back on tired stereotypes because they can‚Äôt be bothered to carry out proper research, go ahead.
Like a structural edit and a line edit and a copy edit, an authenticity read (maybe we should start calling them authenticity edits?) is about making a book better.

I don‚Äôt demand an author change anything, or try to get in the way of their creative process. My job is to identify areas where the book can be strengthened, advise on why I (sometimes strongly) think changes should be made, and then leave it to the author.

What I have done as an authenticity reader is, among other things:
‚Ä¢pointed out where non-English words are used incorrectly
‚Ä¢identified where characters are described using only stereotypes
‚Ä¢highlighted areas where an author is using offensive language or ideas.

This shows a lack of understanding about what sensitivity/authenticity readers do. I‚Äôve never once ‚Äúsanitised‚Äù an author‚Äôs work, never once tried to narrow their imagination. https://t.co/ZkGEnFF3Ca

This is, I realise, an incoherent ramble, but I am so angry. Solidarity, as always, with Chimene, Monisha and Sunny.

This whole thing has been a lesson in how white supremacy works. Discredit the critics, place the wrongdoer as the victim, discredit the critics further by getting ‚Äúpeople like them‚Äù to take the opposite view, give the wrongdoer a victory tour.

This is complete and utter bull and it is also in the vein of the Priti Patel school of performative inclusivity. If Cl*nch* had been ‚Äúcancelled‚Äù like she and these women and others are maintaining, why is she being interviewed and written about and positioned as a victim?

Yes, I‚Äôm talking about the Cl*nch* mess. An establishment is actively fuelling a narrative that positions her as a victim and it‚Äôs now doing so by using brown women to leap to her defence in order to further discredit those brown women who critiqued her work and found it wanting.

Don‚Äôt make the mistake of thinking that just because a couple of brown women are wading in to defend a white woman, that white woman is suddenly cleared of wrongdoing. White supremacy works by using internalised racism to position itself as right and true.
@chimenesuleyman @ProfSunnySingh Wow, there‚Äôs really a mission to bring out the brown women to write about this and position KC as having done no wrong.

It is not hard to do, and your coverage will be better for having people who understand the nuances and significance of seeing this representation on screen.
And if we're being specific, you should be commissioning dark-skinned Asian women to write about Bridgerton and Pakistani Muslim women to write about Ms Marvel.

As always, solidarity with @ProfSunnySingh, @monisha_rajesh and @chimenesuleyman.
And I know that punishes authors and publicists and sales people and so on, but it really seems nothing is getting through to the top right now, and so we have to take these types of actions.

We've already seen bookshops saying they won't stock Picador, and I know people who won't read the list any more. I've been a huge fan of Picador's in the past and I have friends who work there, but right now? I don't think in good conscience I can read what they're producing.

I don't see a way forward without major changes at Picador, because few people have faith that with Philip Gwyn Jones at the helm, any meaningful change can happen. All that is being done is more harm is being done to those who were never, ever in the wrong with their criticism.
Half-hearted, HR-written apologies have never cut it, and they're only making the situation worse now. It is, quite honestly, beyond time for people to lose jobs.

This is a horrifying and stressful way to live, and Sunny, Monisha and Chimene shouldn't have to be doing this. I am filled with rage about what the industry has and continues to do to them. https://t.co/TJNJgbTMC3
Once again, join a union. I'm a member of the NUJ, and if you need a sponsor, you can absolutely put my name down when you fill out your membership application (just tell me first!).

It's clear that individuals, particularly those from minority communities, are at risk of feeling and being scapegoated and attacked, and so I recommend having a union at your back, especially if you feel your employer doesn't or won't stand with you.

Never once did I think about a person I wrote about as a statistic, or only think about them via the way they died. I left death knocks with a real sense of who they were as a person, and my aim was always to infuse that into anything I wrote as a way to pay tribute.

But there was something poignant about sitting down in someone's house and hearing their stories of their loved one, of them showing you photo albums over a cup of tea, of them laughing or shedding a tear over a memory.
At the risk of sounding like I'm 80, I think it's very different now, because people can share their grief and their memories through social media in an immediate way, which has its own positives.

In all my years in local news, and through all the death knocks that I did and stories that I wrote, families were always happy to share their memories, and to have the newspaper articles as a tribute to their loved one.

Death knocks gave family and friends the chance to speak about and remember the person they loved as they were when they were alive, valuable at a time when everyone else wanted them to talk about their death.

I worked in two areas with military barracks, when the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq were at their height. My first job was in Folkestone, and I still remember the names of the Gurkha soldiers whose deaths I had to cover.

Same, and each one was as hard, if not harder than the one before it. I think it can often seem like reporters are vultures, but working in local news I (and my colleagues) approached each death known with respect, and a little bit of sadness. https://t.co/VtwgpN2JvW

@bethklewis It‚Äôs hard, because reviews are precious, and we desperately need books spoken about on big media platforms. I think one thing to do is try and use any benefits of a good review (like interviews) to champion books and authors you love that perhaps wouldn‚Äôt get that opportunity.
Anyway, not sure why I‚Äôm ranting into the void about a publication I should not waste my energy on. Someone send me Hobi pics and gifs to clear my bad mood.

No one publishes a book into a vacuum, and publishing is not a zero sum game. When the industry is doing well overall, it‚Äôs good for everyone involved. We want readers to have options, we want people to be excited about the variety of books being published.

Before I‚Äôm misunderstood, ‚Äúyour‚Äù refers to everyone involved in making a book. And I‚Äôm not saying the DM shouldn‚Äôt review or you shouldn‚Äôt be happy about a review, but do think about how you can use your voice/platform to stand up and promote the work of those being attacked.
Next time a DM quote is splashed across the front of your book, consider the people that were trashed by that very same publication.

The idea that there is a separation between the books desk and the rest of the publication is a defence that only goes so far. If they‚Äôre willing to dump on the rest of the industry and rail against anything they don‚Äôt like, is that something you can stand by?

I know review space is at a premium, and is precious and can be life-changing, but it‚Äôs time we had a discussion about how if you‚Äôre happy to shout about the DM endorsing a book, then you‚Äôre part of the problem.

Also, if I was Hachette I would be p***ed that the article presented it as though David Shelley was talking directly to the outlet for that piece.

It is beyond time that publishers stepped up to the plate and spoke about something that is essential to their work, and is constantly being attacked. We are real people that genuinely improve the work you do, and you mostly sit by and watch us thrown under the bus.

I know for a fact publishers know how useful sensitivity/authenticity reads are, and I also know publishers know there's a nuance to them that just isn't being presented in these hatchet-job articles on the topic.
The people you need to hear from right now, the people who should be stepping in to defend sensitivity/authenticity reads and readers are the publishers who have used them.
But you know what, you don't need to hear from me or other people who do sensitivity/authenticity reads. We are not the ones who should be putting ourselves on the line here.

I really wanted to do a big thread about all the things wrong with the piece, and exactly what it is sensitivity/authenticity readers actually do, with examples. I even wrote the thread out in my head as I tried to drift off to sleep last night.
I made the mistake of reading that piece about sensitivity readers, and I have been incandescent with rage as well as upset and a little frightened ever since.

And I don't even know what the point of this thread is, really, but I can't be the only one feeling like this.
It's been heartbreaking and anxiety-inducing and dispiriting, and some days I can't see anything but the industry tearing itself apart in an effort to remain stagnant.
While I still love books and adore a lot of people who ARE making a difference, mostly I just spend my time feeling incredibly sad whenever I think about what's been happening.
There seems to be something new to battle against each day, something that pulls the industry back a mile for every slow inch it's dragged forward towards being more inclusive and just better.
I've never felt the divide between publishing's "insiders" ‚Äì white, embedded in their ways ‚Äì and those who are trying to make change quite so keenly as I have in the last few months.

I used to tweet a lot about publishing, but the last couple of months it's been really difficult to do so. The industry feels quite hostile in a lot of ways right now, especially for people from minority communities.

Sensitivity readers should be a part of the editorial process, but by no means should they be the only people on the lookout for these issues, and they shouldn‚Äôt be the solution to mistakes made elsewhere in the writing and editing of a book.

Sensitivity reads are a HUGE amount of pressure. Every time I do one, I‚Äôm paranoid about missing something, nervous I‚Äôll not spot something that has the power to harm, and sometimes ashamed of my own ignorance. They are, for me, often emotional labour as well as labour labour.

Sensitivity reads are also not the be all and end all. A sensitivity reader (or readers) cannot possibly pick up on everything, and so having your book sensitivity read can never be an excuse you use for things that still slip through the net.
You wouldn‚Äôt leave all the spelling and grammar mistakes, and all the historical inaccuracies, say, in until proof stage, so why do the same with anything that requires a sensitivity reader?

Sensitivity reads need to come earlier in the process than they currently do. I often get approached when a book is being proofed. If you know you‚Äôre going to need a book sensitivity read, the sensitivity reader should be there from as close to the start as possible.
Sensitivity reads are not the answer to publishing‚Äôs continued missteps. As @redbreastedbird says, the work should really have done by the author before then. https://t.co/ZKAFlk2lof
As someone who regularly does sensitivity reads, a few things to consider, for this book and for the future... https://t.co/KyCfUKxadD
RT @redbreastedbird: I find this concerning. Before a book reaches sensitivity reader stage it should be part of an author‚Äôs due diligence‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm a judge for the @CWIPprize Unpublished Novelist Prize this year, and I‚Äôm glad to see this statement. https://t.co/Z9aFvGLhoh

@Nishawrites Anyway, this long ramble is to say that @Nishawrites has done an amazing job with Radha and Jai's Recipe for Romance, and I hope you'll read it and love it as much as I did! https://t.co/AwVtf9Mg5A

Radha and Jai's Recipe for Romance is beautiful, and touching, and as it's set in the world of dance it also features a bunch of dance scenes @Nishawrites describes so wonderfully you'll see them in your head. Here's a clue about my favourite... https://t.co/r3eg0wR6hI

And it's also a book about dreams: our dreams for ourselves, others' dreams for us, and what happens when something gets in the way of those dreams. How do you find a new dream, a new passion? And how do you let go of your old dream, or adjust it to fit who you are now?

Radha and Jai's Recipe for Romance is also about found family, and has one of the best teachers I have ever met in fiction, and an "uncle" I'd be thrilled to add to my roster of non-relative relatives.

This book is also about the connections between parents and children, and how those aren't always easy. @Nishawrites beautifully captures the difficulties we face when we realise our parents are fallible, and how perhaps that realisation can lead to better relationships.

As per the title, this is at its core a romance novel, with two amazing protagonists who are going to grab your hearts with their first appearances on the page. I could read a book each about Radha and Jai, and together they are just magic.

It's UK publication day for @nishawrites' Radha and Jai's Recipe for Romance, and I wanted to take a moment to say how much I love this book, and what a pleasure it has been working on it as the UK editor. (Amazing cover by Hatecopy!) https://t.co/vOnfUYwnSs

This pair of episodes has not one but two absolutely stunning twists (the second is planned but the first? Woo, boy, no one saw that coming): https://t.co/KHGBVvDV3e #BTS 7/?

The Lucky 777 (episodes 126 and 127) challenge is as high drama as you get, even though it takes place in an office building and involves #BTS having to win a series of stupid games (stacking cups, blowing bubbles etc). 6/? https://t.co/GBJvl47FPa

The four-part short trip (episodes 53 to 56) is very funny. There's Jungkook eating vast amounts of fried chicken and a foot volleyball challenge that shows (thankfully) #BTS aren't good at everything. There's also spanking. Yes, you read that right: https://t.co/Objx6SkyFq 5/?

It's got Hobi screaming his way through everything. And it's got a gift giving that starts off really tacky, and then unexpectedly morphs into something incredibly touching: https://t.co/FuFaufNByc #BTS 4/?

My absolute favourite is the the summer challenge (episodes 83 to 85), where #BTS goes to a waterpark and competes across a series of activities. It's got Jungkook being so amazingly talented at everything that it leads to an unexpected competition. 3/? https://t.co/mWuvxpUHfb

RT @Sara_Rose_G: I don‚Äôt want to start a fight but honestly I felt John Oliver‚Äôs video was pretty balanced & came from a place of care, not‚Ä¶

I am far from the first person who has said the board needs to change; it's something that people have said publicly and privately for a long time. It's disappointing that it's not been separated out (as far as I can see), and it needs to be addressed. 7/7
We need to look at how the fact that all of them are white (you can meet them here: https://t.co/ju4my7ZSwT) affects everything that happens further down the company. 6/?
You can say that there are around 160 people who make key decisions, but there are 15 people who make the ultimate decisions. 5/?
Until that team becomes more inclusive (and it can do that in a variety of ways, I'm not advocating replacing people wholesale!), then change below that level is pretty much meaningless. 4/?

Changing the make-up of those 160-odd roles is important, but true change can only be embedded if it comes from the top. And the top - 15 people who make up the PRH leadership team - are all white. 3/?

But my main thought is that the leadership team, as in the board, needs to be separated out from the senior leadership team PRH has given statistics for (that it says are around 160 people who are key decision makers). 2/?

I have many, many thoughts about this, about the current picture, about the time taken to get to this stage of finally taking action (or saying action will be taken), and more. 1/? https://t.co/rwiCuHva3T

With the world as it is, with conflict deepening and less nuance in political discussions, it's more important than ever that children read books that are both mirrors and windows. These lists will, I hope, help do that. Here's the link again: https://t.co/XAoDkD97Zh #LitinColour
These are "living" documents, so they'll be updated every so often, creating a massive resource for everyone involved in encouraging children to read more inclusively. #LitinColour
And the lists have handy indexes grouped by subject and theme as well, so if you're a teacher looking to encourage reading on a particular topic, you can refer to those indexes. #LitinColour
We've split the lists into one for primary schools and one for secondary schools, each containing more than 100 books. You can access them both here: https://t.co/XAoDkD97Zh #LitinColour

They're publisher agnostic, featuring everyone from huge publishing houses like @PenguinUKBooks and @HachetteUK to independents like @_KnightsOf and @JacarandaBooks. And they cover everything from picture books to biographies to poetry.
For any teachers, librarians, parents and more who want to expand their own reading and those of the children in their lives, these lists provide a great starting point.

I'm passionate about diversifying our school reading lists, and so it's been brilliant working on this #LitinColour project with the amazing @ZNabagereka and Sharifah Grant for the past few months. https://t.co/rC2P23lC2s

And finally, on how he read #shadowandbone: ‚ÄúI would send Leigh selfies of me with each book as I finished it, and she would send me emojis of black hearts back.‚Äù #shadowandbone üñ§üñ§üñ§üñ§ https://t.co/weVecGjeY1

On His Dark Materials, and which part he‚Äôd like to play if he‚Äôd been in the show: ‚ÄúI would have loved to have been in it as any character. I'll be an armoured bear, or Pantalaimon. I suppose the obvious answer is, in a couple of years, Lord Asriel.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I just thought this is so interesting in terms of the themes of all of this, it makes it about identity and makes it about masks, and it makes it about perception instead of making it about a story between a hero and a villain.‚Äù 2/2
On THAT Darkling line: ‚ÄúThe line is not ‚ÄòI'm the villain‚Äô or ‚Äòyou think I'm the villain‚Äô, it‚Äôs ‚Äòmake me your villain‚Äô.‚Äù 1/2 #shadowandbone

On wanting to be in the know with books: ‚ÄúI don't want to miss out on the zeitgeist. I remember not wanting to be the person who hadn't read The Hunger Games, who hadn't read The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, who hadn't read, you know, whatever the thing was.‚Äù

On my queen Inej: ‚ÄúShe's an extraordinary character. For me in the show and the books, there's something about her struggle with whatever her faith system is, and her struggle with wondering whether she deserves this kind of love, that is so human.‚Äù https://t.co/y2cBMEnFdc

On #shadowandbone book fans: ‚ÄúThese are not hubristic readers that recognise themselves because they're like, ‚ÄòI have the power of the sun within me‚Äô, they're just like, ‚Äòthe way she's reacting to this is me‚Äô.‚Äù
‚Äú‚Ä¶when it's assassins and sharp shooters and magical army leaders, to be able to see yourself in those characters, it‚Äôs quite a feat, actually.‚Äù 3/3
‚ÄúHaving fans of the books come on, and [seeing] how much these characters mean to them in terms of identity, of seeing themselves in characters, which if you think about it‚Ä¶‚Äù 2/3

On Leigh Bardugo (@LBardugo) and the #grishaverse: ‚ÄúShe's super cool. And even more impressive since we‚Äôve been doing press, she‚Äôs so erudite in the way she talks about it, it means so much.‚Äù 1/3

‚ÄúIt's a sort of Benjamin Button imagined history, imagine how many loves he must've lost. Imagine how, even if it's not on the page, what it must've been like feel that responsible for that long.‚Äù 2/2

On The Darkling‚Äôs vulnerability (spoiler for the Shadow and Bone trilogy ahead): ‚ÄúI remember with the death of his mother where she falls back off the cliff and it's this sort of sacrificial thing to spite him, it wounds him and you know there must be love lost.‚Äù 1/2

‚ÄúSo it was like, if he's powerful, where is he vulnerable? If he's vulnerable, why is he vulnerable? If he's powerful, does that make him isolated? And if he's lonely, does that steel him and make him cold? Or does that make him thirsty for some kind of human connection?‚Äù 4/4

‚ÄúI always think, what would the exact opposite of this scene be? Because there's obviously big scale allegory, light versus dark; there‚Äôs always a piece of Iight in dark and a piece of dark in light. To be able to even understand what it is and that duality interests me.‚Äù 3/4
‚ÄúAnd also just to scratch deep enough down to find that kernel, that little kernel of hope, like that little part of him, which might not be fully lost, fully dead, fully irredeemable.‚Äù 2/4

On how he approached playing The Darkling: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs interesting to play someone that by any modern standard, his behaviour is uncondonable. He's a problematic character by any standards, but it is interesting to chart that journey in terms of motivation and self belief.‚Äù 1/4 https://t.co/61pRctvC68

@bakingfiction Oh Kate. Thank you for sharing, it will help so many women. Sending you much love. x

We are brought up to take these "preventative" measures, these measures that will keep us safe. But faced with a man who wants to harm us, there is very little we can really do. That's the knowledge we live with every day, and that haunts us even more on days like today.

And yet, ever since I was 14, when it is dark and I am out alone, I remember these tips. And I know that should it come down to it, they are probably no more help to me than holding my keys in my hands and tucking my ponytail under my coat.
It was so matter of fact. There was no acknowledgement that these aren't things women, and especially girls, should have to think about.

It is, to put it crudely, completely f***ed up that these were things I was taught as a child, and that while I was being taught them there was no discussion about men being in the wrong if this happened to us. No talk about how it wasn't our fault if something happened.

Failing that, we should bite down on hard on one side of his lip, and then pull back even harder, in an attempt to rip his lip off. Or we should try and ram our fingers as far up his nose as they could possibly go.

When I was 14, at my all girls' school, we had a self-defence course as part of PE. We were taught that if someone (someone being a man) attacked us, we should try and push our fingers into his eyes and then pull down, to try and incapacitate him as much as possible.

I'm just sad. I absolutely want us to do whatever means we all stay safe, but it is the government's incompetence that has led us to this point where for the second year in a row we're facing a restricted Ramadan, and I am sad, and I am angry, and I don't apologise for that.
I don't know if it's better or worse that the current date for all restrictions to be lifted is falling just after the end of Ramadan.
And of course, it looks like Eid prayers are likely a no go as well, at least for the majority of people, since again, mosques are unlikely to be allowed to fill to capacity.

In addition, we won't be able to socialise indoors, so once again, no iftars. It's not the main point of Ramadan, but I love joining with friends and family (and strangers) to break fasts. I'm devastated that for the second year in a row we can't do that.

Selfish as it is, I am incredibly sad that we'll be doing another Ramadan at home. It's unclear what rules around places of worship are, but it is clear that we won't be able to have full capacity at mosques, so very few people will be able to go to tarawih. https://t.co/y4gINr9ya8

@mushenska @MauraWilding @bronzebygold I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs a nightmare, but tie ins aren‚Äôt the crux of the problem (the first Bridgerton tie in is available). The issue is that the remaining books - all related to this huge phenomenon and which can‚Äôt have tie ins because we haven‚Äôt met the characters - aren‚Äôt there.

@MauraWilding @bronzebygold I‚Äôve said elsewhere that I think publishing needs to build relationships with film and TV companies to help with this. I know that‚Äôs easier said than done, but it‚Äôs clearly crucial.

@mmdotcox @thefingersofgod I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs an easy issue to ‚Äúsolve‚Äù, because it involves the cultivation of relationships where publishing doesn‚Äôt really have them, a wholesale change in attitudes towards certain genres and readers, and more. So it‚Äôs good we‚Äôre discussing it!

@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden (And I am sorry about that job interview, which smacks of an industry that can't see beyond its narrow idea of what a reader is and wants. Which is a related but other issue.)
@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden There's an opportunity there we're just missing.

@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden And I know you know your fandom, but I'm not sure as a whole publishing gets that mindset of seeing something, falling in love with it, searching out the books obsessively, reading tumblr posts (or whatever the kids are doing nowadays).

@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden The publisher did get the first book out in a tie-in cover, and it looks great. But I think there's some work to be done on understanding what a show can do not just for one book, but a whole series.

@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden But I think there are still things publishers can do. Tie-ins are pretty awful, and as a general rule, I avoid them where possible. But some smart new covers (to be used on both physical and digital editions) wouldn't have gone amiss.

@thefingersofgod @cmccrudden I think these are all excellent points, and it does speak to a bigger issue about the way commercial fiction geared towards women (or genre fiction, or YA fiction) is viewed by the industry as a whole. I don't know how we solve that, apart from waiting for the old guard to leave!

@cmccrudden At the latest, all the books should have been repackaged and ready to go ASAP after the teaser trailer was dropped and it was clear people were going to watch. That should have been planned.

An addition/aside: @bridgerton shared this very funny video of the show‚Äôs cast reading from the first book, and this is exactly the kind of content book publishers should be clamouring for when it comes to adaptations. https://t.co/WIbX0u9gXO

@bronzebygold We‚Äôve had Bridgerton, TATBILB, The Witcher and The Queen‚Äôs Gambit, and that‚Äôs just on Netflix. And they‚Äôve all been huge, but publishing (including retail) needs to anticipate that conversation so they can prepare to partake in it when it‚Äôs happening, and not a month later.

@bronzebygold I think, like many publishing problems, lots of different parts of the chain need to do their bit. And for retailers, it‚Äôs again about having someone whose role involves really tapping into the power and potential of adaptations.

@acaseforbooks @katbrown The tie-in for the first book is lovely, it‚Äôs got the gorgeous colour palette. But I had to buy the rest in, as Anna says, classic regency style, and they look so old-fashioned, and I‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôd appeal to people coming from the TV show.
@katierpacker Publishers should have dedicated staff, and part of their role, I think, is advocating about publishing‚Äôs importance in the process beyond a tie-in cover.
@katbrown I read so many of the True Blood books, and it was solely because of the TV show.

@katierpacker I agree, but it has to go beyond editors (and marketers/publicists). Are there people within publishers whose role is building relationships with film/TV people? And not to sell rights, but to understand who an adaptation targets, how it will be marketed, expected audience etc.

@jamiefewery I guess part of the problem is the lack of relationships with film and TV companies. Few publishers have deep connections/involvement with those developing books, and so all that information they need is missing.

@EvanCateAndries My local library service (consisting of multiple libraries) only has one of the books, which I have placed a reservation on. If the library wanted to purchase more books for its borrowers, it wouldn't be able to. I think you've missed the point of the thread?

@BeeBabs Exactly! Especially with a series like this where people will have only briefly met some characters they really like. Viewers will eagerly turn to the books to spend more time with those characters.
In the meantime, I've managed to find a box set of the first five #Bridgerton books on some obscure site I'd never previously heard of, and while I wait for that to arrive, I've turned to trusty AO3.

All this to say, publishing needs to be better at anticipating the particular demand that comes from adaptations of older books, and at understanding the behaviour of people wanting to purchase books they've been introduced to via another medium.
I still think too many people in the industry don‚Äôt think about books as pop culture, as something to binge in the way we do TV, and I also don‚Äôt think publishing really understands fan culture.
But I also know there is a ready of audience of people out there who don‚Äôt know that, and who expect their appetites to be fed. If they‚Äôre not, they‚Äôll find something else to obsess over.
I understand producing books takes time, and I know the past year has been tougher than ever on everything from production to printing.

This isn‚Äôt the first time I‚Äôve encountered this problem. When the adaptation of To All the Boys I‚Äôve Loved Before was released, physical copies of the book were unavailable for a long time. Too long, given what a hit the film was.

A quick look at eBay, and you can see that individuals have responded to the demand - a raft of new listings have gone up, including some outrageously priced ones. A friend in Australia is having the same problem, and had to source the books via a second hand bookshop.
So imagine my surprise when I went to purchase Julia Quinn‚Äôs other books, and found that physical copies were largely unavailable from multiple retailers.

#Bridgerton, the TV show, has been huge: it‚Äôs been number one in the UK, and in other countries, pretty much since its release. This wasn‚Äôt hard to predict, given that it‚Äôs based on a set of hugely successful books and is from Shondaland, which is behind hit show after hit show.

Having reading the first #Bridgerton book and binged the show, I of course wanted to buy the other books so I could indulge in more of my favourite romance tropes (enemies to lovers, unrequited love, buckets of angst).
A quick little thread on publishing, film/TV adaptations, and identifying and tapping in to fan demand‚Ä¶

@brownbookworm I have just finished! Let me know if you want to discuss.

@brownbookworm I didn't need an explanation of the way race is viewed because a) I know Black people were part of London society at that time and b) I know this particular story is fiction. That the show includes a two-minute discussion on race erodes the world it builds, if that makes sense.

@brownbookworm Whereas if the show had perhaps said "we're set in a completely alternative version of your world where slavery and racism don't exist", it would have been a different viewing experience perhaps.

@brownbookworm I agree, and the acknowledgement that the world of the show used to be a racist society contributes to that fight. Once the show explicitly acknowledges that, I then spiral and start thinking about how it changed, and if the wealth of the people is built on slavery (it is).

@AlwynFJH It took me out of the narrative for the show to say "a royal marriage rid our world of racism BUT that is tenuous", and then somehow expects us to still believe in a world which shows not a single sign that racism and racist structures ever existed.
@ubah_egal I completely agree, I think my badly explained point is that we didn‚Äôt need an explanation for the casting. It could just be.
@ubah_egal Of course it‚Äôs a period piece so maybe I‚Äôm thinking too much about it, and should concentrate on all the aspects I am enjoying and not finding puzzling!

@ubah_egal I can understand that, but I think those things stand at odds with one another. And it doesn‚Äôt work time wise - no king‚Äôs decree would result in such a thorough dismantling of racism and racist structures in that amount of time.

@lizzycampbell Completely. I know Hastings answers back and says love doesn't conquer all, and that society could revert at any moment, but we know racism and racist structures take longer than a reign to disappear, so it just doesn't work in the history of the world.

I would love to see someone exploring this aspect of #Bridgerton¬†, and what that means history in the show‚Äôs world looked like (because if we know anything, it‚Äôs that a white royal marrying a Black person does not suddenly stop racists being racists). 6/6

This comment from Lady Danbury felt at odds with the fact of #Bridgerton itself existing as it does, and it felt shoehorned in by some exec who wanted an explanation of why the male lead is a Black man, when actually, we didn‚Äôt need an explanation at all. 5/6

There is, so far, little indication of our real-world racism in the world of #Bridgerton, so are we to believe that in that world, one marriage (albeit the most important marriage in London society) and a few decades completely rid society of racism? 4/?

The implication is that the world of #Bridgerton¬†¬†was racist until a white king fell in love with a Black woman and bam! White people realised Black people were the same as them, all because of one marriage. 3/?

I wasn‚Äôt really thinking much about #Bridgerton‚Äôs inclusivity, and then in episode four Lady Danbury says: ‚ÄúWe were two separate societies, divided by colour until a king fell in love with one of us. Love, your grace, conquers all.‚Äù 2/?
So I‚Äôm four episodes into #Bridgerton and keen to read a piece on how the incidental inclusivity of the show itself seems to clash with the world the show is set in. 1/?

#BooksToNourish, even before its official ‚Äúlaunch‚Äù, has shown the generosity and and heart at the centre of publishing. I‚Äôm hoping, in the coming weeks, we‚Äôll see lots of excellent things put forward for auction, and lots of bidding to raise money money for FareShare.
#BooksToNourish is inspired by the work of Marcus Rashford, and the generosity of people across the country who have stepped in to help children facing hardship where the government refused to do so.

The auction will be open for bids from Monday, November 9 to Sunday, November 22. Bids will be placed via comments on each item‚Äôs page, with the highest bid at the time the auction closes winning. More details on how to bid will be on the #BooksToNourish website soon.

The deadline to submit auction lots is 11.59pm on Sunday, November 1 (THIS Sunday). More information on auction items and the auction in general can be found on the #BooksToNourish website: https://t.co/oqZb5yJ32M

#BooksToNourish is looking for book-related things, anything from a cookbook author offering a Zoom cooking lesson to an exclusive print of an illustration to an advice session with agents. If you want to submit an item, there‚Äôs a Google Form here: https://t.co/asqVlkVgDo

For this part of #BooksToNourish, we‚Äôre on the hunt for auction lots. A number of you have already been in touch to offer up bundles of books, editorial manuscript reviews and signed books, which are all amazing, but the auction still needs more items for people to bid on.

Calling all book fans, please welcome #BooksToNourish, a charity auction to raise money for @FareShareUK, the UK‚Äôs longest running food redistribution charity. All you need to know about the first stage of Books to Nourish is contained within this thread‚Ä¶ https://t.co/f0dPBRZzsn

@katyaellis_ @dawniewalton Loling at my face!
@mmdotcox I‚Äôm going to hold you to this.

@redbreastedbird I think outlets need to examine how/why reviews are assigned. Reviews are, I believe, for readers. They're not for clickbait, and I can cite a number of reviews that have just been published to provoke. That's only partially on the critic, but mostly on the publication.

@EAClarkAuthor @RuthWareWriter And no review should be trashing a book. There's a difference between a hatchet job and real criticism, in my opinion. One is just mean, the other aims to help the reader (a very basic summary of my thoughts).

@redbreastedbird And I think a review about a book needs to be about that book. It shouldn't be about sneering at readers or authors, or a chance to dump on a genre you don't like. It should be about the writing, the plot, the characters, the meaning etc etc. (But that's idealistic, I know!)

@redbreastedbird This is why I think we need a discussion on how criticism works. It's silly for books to be reviewed by people predisposed to dislike them i.e. because they've previously shown disregard for the genre, or because they're clearly so far out of the target reader it's laughable.

@EAClarkAuthor @RuthWareWriter I think that's a really good point, and I think it's all part of a big discussion that's needed around criticism, who it's for, what it should be touching on, and how to criticise constructively and respectfully (both towards the author and the reader). Does that make sense?

We started work on Our Town quite a while ago, and it‚Äôs lovely to see it all come to fruition today with the help of all the people named, and so many more besides. Please buy Afraid of the Dark, or borrow it from your local library, and I hope you enjoy reading it.

And @lucyfarfort was the illustrator we found! Her submission of a market scene and a family photo made it clear that she just 'got' Our Town. She‚Äôs perfectly brought to life the place and the families living there, and stamped the book with her own vision.

This book came about in discussions with @truongthomas, and we all decided we really wanted to find a new illustration talent for it, so we launched a long search with a really awkward video (with lots of help from @LaceyPR and @charlieinabook). https://t.co/lpegdBtNo6

It was important to us all that Our Town had a library. Stories are key to our imagining of the world, and a library makes books and stories accessible. There‚Äôs a really gorgeous spread by @lucyfarfort in Afraid of the Dark that centres the library. https://t.co/R5SFxFtaKV

The wonderful @EmmaJen59296938 created a map of Our Town, showing where all the families we‚Äôd imagined lived, and what the rest of the town looked like. Here's a peek at that map. https://t.co/opVSDmw1NI

We knew we wanted Our Town - Afraid of the Dark's setting - to look like our world, and also be aspirational. With designer @EmmaJen59296938 we talked a lot about the town‚Äôs environmental credentials, from imagining car-free areas to ensuring it had green spaces and a train line.

It contains bios for all our characters, some of whom you meet in Afraid of the Dark, others who you will hopefully encounter in future books. We know what our characters‚Äô personalities are, who they‚Äôre friends with, the types of houses they live in, and much more.
Afraid of the Dark is 28 pages, but me and @IsabelOtter  created the equivalent of a ‚Äúshow bible‚Äù for it, which has a lot of info in it.

It‚Äôs publication day for Afraid of the Dark, illustrated by @lucyfarfort. It‚Äôs an absolutely beautiful book, and I wanted to share a few behind-the-scenes tidbits about its creation, because a book takes a village.

RT @cmccrudden: Your regular, friendly reminder that "cancel culture" does not exist outside of the pages of news periodicals, and the rest‚Ä¶

What's changed is that the people affected by these books, who are marginalised further or hurt, whose voices weren‚Äôt heard or listened to, can speak out on platforms where they are heard. And publishers don't know how to deal with that.
And I have a problem with the idea that the ‚Äúlimits of what is acceptable to publish are shifting‚Äù. It‚Äôs never been ok to publish racist or homophobic books (as two examples).

I think it also shows a fundamental misunderstanding of why books/companies are criticised, and doesn't take into account how the people criticising are harmed and hurt by the books, and the reactions to their concerns.

I think it plays into a narrative that books are regularly ‚Äúcancelled‚Äù. I can of very, very few examples (not even a handful) of books that weren‚Äôt published following criticism. Even then, those books were criticised beyond the social media sphere.

There is A LOT more that the industry can do, and should do, but these steps only take a couple of minutes to understand, and can be enacted now. There are no excuses not to take them on board.

Agents - update your websites. They need clear information about authors you represent, books you like, and whether you‚Äôre open to submissions, and they need your contact information on them. If you‚Äôre expecting people to come to you, then make it easy for them to do so.

Reviewers/critics - if you read a proof and find racist sentiments/sentences/ideas and/or a portrayal of Black people based on stereotypes, email the publicist to point it out. Don‚Äôt let it lie and assume someone else will notice, or that it‚Äôs not a big enough thing to point out.

Retailers - look at where you‚Äôre placing books by Black authors in your bookshop. Have you got them on tables? Are these books face out? Do you choose them for window displays? If your answer is no, time to rearrange.

Also for publicists, and related to my point about authors, examine the line ups for festivals and venues that you‚Äôre pitching authors to. Ensure they‚Äôre inclusive, and if they‚Äôre not, flag it with them.

Publicists - don‚Äôt ignore Black reviewers/critics for 95% of the books you‚Äôre working on, and then only get in touch when you have a book by a Black author or illustrator. It‚Äôs really, really obvious, and really, really not appreciated.

Authors - if you‚Äôre invited to take part in a festival, ask who else is invited and what they‚Äôre speaking about. If the line up has no Black writers, or if Black writers are only asked to speak about identity or Black pain, say you won‚Äôt speak until the festival does better.
There are lots of big, structural changes needed in publishing to make it more inclusive, but these are things that individuals can do, and can do immediately‚Ä¶

Have deleted my original thread about small steps in publishing. It was rightly criticised for not acknowledging the unique hurdles faced by Black people in publishing, and I‚Äôm sorry for that. I‚Äôve reframed, and here it is again.

There have been some truly excellent poetry collections published in recent years, and these in particular I think are amazing:
There Are More Beautiful Things Than Beyonc√© by Morgan Parker

I read a lot of YA, and I‚Äôd press these books into the hands of teenagers and adults alike:
Piecing Me Together by Ren√©e Watson

Noughts + Crosses by Malorie Blackman https://t.co/RprWuzbAim

Fiction cont...

Adult fiction... Some of these are serious, some lighthearted. Some contain pain, some contain joy, others contain both:

Get A Life, Chloe Brown - Talia Hibbert

(Cont...) https://t.co/o6mowyQvkm

Continuing with non-fiction but delving into ‚Äúworkbook‚Äù style texts, I found both Diversify by June Sarpong and Me and White Supremacy by Layla F Saad useful and thought-provoking. They both force readers to question our own behaviours, which is essential. https://t.co/l2zZOFESeX

Non-fic cont...
Don‚Äôt Touch My Hair - Emma Dabiri
Hostile Environment - Maya Goodfellow
Brit(ish) - Afua Hirsch
Mother Country ed by Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
The Good Immigrant ed by Nikesh Shukla https://t.co/iztsmSra1e

These non-fic books got me thinking about race, class, privilege and belonging in different ways, and helped me better understand all those things and more:
Why I‚Äôm No Longer Talking to White People About Race - Reni Eddo-Lodge
Natives - Akala
Superior by Angela Saini
(Cont...) https://t.co/zdNbZFuTMj

These lists are by no means exhaustive (I'll remember 10 books I should have included as soon as I've posted the titles), and I‚Äôd welcome any additions (I mostly read books by women, so there‚Äôs a big gap in my reading, and I don‚Äôt often read younger than YA).

Of the fiction and poetry books I‚Äôm including, some are focused on race, but others aren‚Äôt. All of them are on this list because they‚Äôre excellent; they‚Äôve entertained me, made me laugh, made me cry, made me love, made me think. For these, I‚Äôve focused on books by black authors.
The non-fiction books I‚Äôve picked ARE about race and have taught me something and made me think about my own attitudes and activism. Many, but not all, of these books are by black people.

Part of our self-education is to not think about books by black writers (and writers of colour more generally) only in terms of how much they can ‚Äúteach‚Äù us. Our self-education should also be about books that are about life in all its facets.
In the end, I‚Äôve decided to share books that fit the original query, but also books that aren‚Äôt specifically about race.

Someone slid into my DMs a few days ago to ask me to share a list of titles people should be looking at for self-education on race. It‚Äôs taken me a while to get my thoughts together as to what would be most useful.

Last, last thing: I‚Äôve seen some people talking about how the things AR said are the sort you say in a pub to friends, not in an interview and it worries me so much that people think private micro aggressions, prejudice and racism are ok. A racist in private is still a racist.
Grr, typo! Meant English isn‚Äôt their first language. https://t.co/zsQ7RmcaDq
Your inferiority complex is showing. The fact that you feel threatened is showing. And you need to reassess your in jokes.

We understand these women perfectly well when they speak English, we know what they're saying without difficulty, and you want to use the fact that they misplaced a tiny word here or there to feel better about yourself?

Many immigrant women, including my mum, might miss out prepositions, or sometimes use the wrong tense. But you know what? My mum speaks three languages. Many immigrant women have multiple languages under their belt.

Mocking people for not speaking English well enough (to an arbitrary standard decided by the person criticising) is just another way of viewing English (and therefore whiteness) as dominant, and everyone else as other.

Rather, I just want to add a couple of sentences about generally mocking people's accents and the way they phrase things if English isn't their second language. It's a really easy way to make fun of someone and it demeans them.

One last thing on the AR situation and then I promise I'll stop - the "please to buy my cutting board" comment was particularly hurtful. There's no justifying it as an inside joke, but I'm not really concerned with her explanation of why she used it. https://t.co/1Yv6MscfIZ
Reign. Have you seen that couture? https://t.co/iicx2SrbLa
A way to support both Chrissy Teigen and Marie Kondo is to follow their work. Both have Instagram accounts that are full of colour and joy, and that put a smile on my face.
All this to say that racism comes in many forms, and I'm sad that Chrissy Teigen and Marie Kondo have been treated this way.
Similarly, Teigen works hard and is passionate about her love for food and cooking, and her classy response to what's happened made me tear up: https://t.co/6nIDImnnQd

I recently read Joy at Work, Kondo's latest book, and in it it's clear how hard Kondo has worked for years and years and years, and to dismiss her ventures now as "b***h, you f***ing just sold out immediately" is heinous.

It's interesting that Marie Kondo has regularly been greeted with racism in the western world. This Taffy Brodesser-Akner piece from 2016 reports on how other organisational experts responded to Kondo with "aggressive xenophobia and racism": https://t.co/HLjMmEDrbK
Anyone who has engaged with Marie Kondo's work knows her philosophy can't be boiled down to "don't have stuff", and if that's what you think, you're wilfully misunderstanding her and what she does.
That Marie Kondo was called a "b***h" is absolutely horrible. It's such a gendered insult and really disgusting, and there's really no forgiving it.

I've been thinking about (and discussing) the Marie Kondo and Chrissy Teigen thing all morning, and it breaks my heart that two incredible women who are passionate about their work were attacked in such a horrible way.
